Candidatus Bandiella euplotis is a recently discovered bacterial species that has been classified as a member of the Candidate phylum Bandicootbacteria. This bacterium was first identified and named based on its association with the marine ciliate protozoan Euplotes, a genus of single-celled eukaryotes found in various aquatic environments.

The taxonomic classification of Candidatus Bandiella euplotis is as follows:
Domain: Bacteria
Phylum: Candidatus Bandicootbacteria
Class: Candidatus Bandicootia
Order: Candidatus Bandicootales
Family: Candidatus Bandiellaceae
Genus: Candidatus Bandiella
Species: Candidatus Bandiella euplotis

Candidatus Bandiella euplotis is an obligate endosymbiont, meaning it lives within the cells of its Euplotes host. It is believed to have a mutualistic relationship with the ciliate, potentially providing metabolic or other benefits to its host in exchange for nutrients and a stable environment. However, the precise nature of this symbiotic interaction is still under investigation.

As a member of the Candidate phylum Bandicootbacteria, Candidatus Bandiella euplotis represents an example of the diverse and understudied microbial life forms that exist in close association with various eukaryotic organisms, particularly in marine ecosystems. Further research on this species and its relatives can contribute to our understanding of the complex interactions and interdependencies within microbial communities.
